title: Costa’s best hope might be for things to get worse
text:
Headroom, breathing space, buying time – given those banks are so super friendly, I guess you can call it what you want.

If you didn’t buy the just-a-bit-of-headroom line, then Debney had a different sales slant, explaining that Costa hadn’t raised capital since its IPO in 2015, despite spending $400 million on five big expansion projects.

In other words, investors can see this as a rather very late invoice for growth previously delivered.

To be fair, Costa’s business is being smashed by a combination of drought and oversupply, which have weighed on market conditions for its various produce categories.

Blueberry, farms are being put on the sale block, or converted back into hobby farms. Shutterstock

It's not alone in battling these conditions. On Tuesday morning, Bega Cheese delivered a profit warning due to drought pushing up milk costs and demand in export markets sagging.

But having downgraded profits in January and May, Costa now says it will deliver lease-adjusted EBITDA of $98 million in calendar 2019 – well under consensus for $137.9 million and – and $150 million in 2020. But this is predicated on a “modest improvement of dry weather and drought conditions”. That seems a big caveat.

But Debney emphasised that hat as Australia’s largest grower and packer of fresh fruit and vegetables, Costa is best placed to withstand the tumult going through the industry.

In some categories, Debney said, smaller producers are likely to be operating at a loss or close to it. In others, such as blueberries, farms are being put on the sale block, or converted back into hobby farms.

The suggestion was that Costa’s competitive advantage should be enhanced if it can ride this out, and wait for the inevitable consolidation.

Debney might be right. But will investors be willing to take the risk?
description: After three profit downgrades and deeply discounted capital raising, Costa Group's message to investors is that it's best placed to ride out industry tumult.
